title: 114_hr1266
content: The Act titled "Financial Product Safety Commission Act of 2015" establishes the Bureau as an independent Financial Product Safety Commission. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to change the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection to the Financial Product Safety Commission, an independent commission. Subsections (b), (c), and (d) are removed. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to change the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection to the Financial Product Safety Commission, an independent commission. Subsections (b), (c), and (d) are removed, and the Commission is granted authority to prescribe regulations and issue orders as necessary for carrying out its jurisdiction. The Financial Product Safety Commission, an independent commission, is composed of 5 members appointed by the President with strong competencies related to consumer financial products. Members serve staggered terms initially set by the President for 1-5 years. Each member of the Financial Product Safety Commission, including the Chair, serves a 5-year term and can be removed by the President for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, and members can continue to serve until a successor is appointed. The Financial Product Safety Commission members serve 5-year terms, can be removed by the President, and vacancies are filled until a successor is appointed. Members cannot engage in other employment, and no more than 3 members can be from the same political party. The Chair is appointed by the President and has executive authority over the Commission. The Chair of the Financial Product Safety Commission has executive authority over the appointment and supervision of personnel, distribution of business, and use of funds. The Chair's functions are limited by the Commission's general policies and regulatory decisions. The Chair of the Financial Product Safety Commission must obtain prior approval from the Commission for requests or estimates related to appropriations. Vacancies in the Commission do not impair the remaining members' ability to exercise the Commission's powers, with a quorum of three members required for business transactions. The Financial Product Safety Commission can operate with a quorum of 2 members during vacancies. The Commission must have an official seal and compensation rates are specified for the Chair and other members. Certain sections regarding appointments and recommendations are being amended. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to require the appointment of members based on recommendations from regional Federal Reserve Bank Presidents. Additionally, a total of $75,000,000 is to be transferred from the surplus funds of Federal reserve banks to the Treasury's general fund in fiscal year 2016, with the specific amounts determined by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The system will determine the payment amount for each bank in the fiscal year. No Federal reserve bank can replenish its surplus fund during fiscal years 2016 through 2026 by the amount transferred under paragraph (1). SEC. 3. DEEMING OF NAME. Any reference to the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection in US laws or documents will now be considered a reference to the Financial Product Safety Commission. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to replace references to the Director of the Bureau with the Financial Product Safety Commission. This includes changing references to "Director" to "Financial Product Safety Commission" except in specific cases. Additionally, paragraph (10) in section 1002 is removed. In section 1013, references to the Assistant Director are replaced with "Head of the Office" and "Head of the Office of Financial Protection for Older Americans". The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended to replace references to the Director of the Bureau with the Financial Product Safety Commission in various sections of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. This change includes replacing "Director" with "Financial Product Safety Commission" in specific instances. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 replaces references to the Director of the Bureau with the Financial Product Safety Commission in various sections of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, including the Electronic Fund Transfer Act, Expedited Funds Availability Act, and Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 updates references to the Director of the Bureau with the Financial Product Safety Commission in multiple financial regulations. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 updates references to the Director of the Bureau with the Financial Product Safety Commission in various financial regulations, such as the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act of 1975 and the Interstate Land Sales Full Disclosure Act. The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 and the S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 are amended to replace references to the Director of the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection with the Financial Product Safety Commission. The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 and the S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 are amended to replace references to the Director of the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection with the Financial Product Safety Commission in various sections of the United States Code. The Act and its amendments will come into effect once at least 3 members of the Financial Product Safety Commission are confirmed by the Senate.
